B17
IN SUPPORT OF A PETITION TO BE PRESENTED TO CONGRESS
ASKING FOR A PENSION FOR THE WIDOW AND CHIL-
DREN OF DR. J. W. LAZEAR, WHO DIED IN THE ARMY
SERVICE AS ACTING ASSISTANT SURGEON, AT QUEMA-
DOS, CUBA, UNDER CIRCUMSTANCES OF EXTRAORDINARY
SELF-SACRIFICE AND COURAGE.

On the 25th of September, 1900, Jesse William Lazear, Acting Assist-
ant Surgeon in the United States Army and a member of the Government
Commission for the investigation of yellow fever lost his life from that
disease at Quemados, Cuba. The circumstances leading to this sad
event were of a very unusual character. Lazear was a native of Balti-
more County, Maryland, a graduate of the Johns Hopkins University,
and of the Medical Department of Columbia University, New York. He
had pursued important studies and investigations in Europe and in the
laboratories of the Johns Hopkins University and hospital in Baltimore,
and was a member of the staff of the hospital and an instructor in the
University. In February, 1900, he was induced by the opportunity for
research concerning malarial and yellow fevers to enter the United States
Army as an Acting Assistant Surgeon and was assigned especial labora-
tory duties at Columbia Barracks near Havana. Later he was appointed
by Surgeon-General Sternberg a member of the Government Commission
for the investigation of yellow fever of which Major Reed was chairman.

To the brilliant discoveries of this Commission, Lazear contributed
largely. The investigations of the Commission led the members to the
belief that a certain form of mosquito played an important part in the
transmission of the poison of yellow fever. A time was reached, however,
when the final proof of this hypothesis could only be determined by
direct experiment upon human beings. To this experiment Lazear and
another member of the Commission subjected themselves. His friend ac-
quired the disease and recovered, Lazear escaped. Shortly afterwards,
however, he repeated the experiment, allowing himself to be bitten by a
mosquito in a yellow fever ward. In this manner he acquired the dis-
ease which resulted fatally.

These two positive cases justified the Commission in making conclusions
which have since then been entirely confirmed. This discovery has
brought about results of incalculable public importance. By demon-
strating, for the first time, the method by which yellow fever is acquired
it has afforded positive and accurate means for protection of the public
against the disease, with the result that, within one year, the city of
Havana has been entirely freed from this malady.

No sacrifice could be more deliberate or courageous than that of Lazear,
and the great results which have followed should insure to his memory
the lasting gratitude of his fellow countrymen.

Dr. Lazear left a wife and two children in circumstances which oblige
her to apply for a pension. Surely no soldier dead in battle could deserve
more from his country than this man who by deliberately sacrificing his
life has contributed to the saving of thousands of others.

From the Surgeon-General of the United States Army.
SURGEON-GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, January 13, 1902.

I take pleasure in testifying to the value of the services rendered
by Dr. Jesse William Lazear, who lost his life in Cuba, from yellow fever,
while engaged in experimental researches relating to the cause and pre-
vention of this disease, in compliance with Orders from the War Department
assigning him to duty as a member of a board appointed for this purpose.
The results attained by this board are of the utmost importance and will,
without doubt, result in the saving of many valuable lives. I therefore feel
justified in earnestly recommending legislation by the Congress of the United
States providing a suitable pension for the widow of Dr. Lazear who is left
with two children in destitute circumstances.

GEO. M. STERNBERG,
Surgeon-General, U. S. Army.

From the President of the Army Board of Medical Officers
appointed to investigate the prevalence of Yellow Fever in Cuba.

As senior member of the Board of Medical Officers convened by Special
Orders, No. 122, Adjutant-General's Office, Washington, May 24th, 1900, for
the scientific investigation of yellow fever on the Island of Cuba, I cannot
speak too highly of the services of the late Dr. Jesse W. Lazear, Acting
Assistant Surgeon, U. S. A.

As a member of this Board he displayed at all times an enthusi-
astic and fearless devotion to duty which was worthy of the highest com-
mendation. He repeatedly risked his life by entering houses that were badly
infected with yellow fever, in order that he might gain, if possible, some
knowledge of the spread of this disease; and later when it became desirable
to test the transmission of the disease by means of the bite of infected
mosquitoes, Dr. Lazear unhesitatingly offered himself for the experiment.
In thus voluntarily sacrificing his life he had no other object in view than
the good that might thereby come to his fellow man. Although holding no
commission in the Regular Army, Dr. Lazear, in my opinion, died as plainly
in the line of duty as any officer or soldier who had ever fallen in battle.

WALTER REED,
Major and Surgeon, U. S. A.,
President of the Board.
Washington, D. C.,
January 11, 1902.
